hints.content:
$\blueD{4} \times (\maroonD{3} \times \greenD{6})$ can represent $\blueD{4}$ groups of $\maroonD{3}$ groups of $\greenD{6}$.

![4 groups of 3 groups of 6 dots](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/980e56677e3bb3b544c3d424454fdc7648c9e27c)

How can we complete $(\blueD{4} \times{\maroonD{?}})\times \greenD{6}$ to get the same total?

We can think of $(\blueD{4} \times{\maroonD{?}})\times \greenD{6}$ as $(\blueD{4} \times {\maroonD{?}})$ groups of $\greenD{6}$.   

![The same dots in 12 groups of 6. The groups are in 4 columns with 3 groups per column](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/39422e954d9577e9dcfceb7564ffa0e45c7898eb)

There are $\purpleC{12}$ groups of $\greenD{6}$, which equals $(\blueD{4} \times {\maroonD{3}})$ groups of $\greenD{6}$.

We can change the grouping of the factors without changing the total.  

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
As long as we're only multiplying, we can group the factors in any way without changing the total product.

We call that the **associative property of multiplication**.

It does *not* work when we mix multiplication with other operations like addition.

For example:

$\begin{align}
2+(3 \times 4) &\neq (2 + 3) \times 4\\\\
2+12 &\neq 5 \times 4\\\\
14 &\neq 20
\end{align}$
